hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![2 rows of cookies. Row 1 has 3 cookies. Row 2 has 3 cookies. Vertical dotted lines divide the cookies into 3 columns so there are 3 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![2 columns of cookies. Column 1 has 3 cookies. Column 2 has 2 cookies. Horizontal dotted lines divide the cookies into 3 rows so there are 2 pairs with 1 extra cookie.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\blueE{14}$ apples.

![2 rows of apples. Row 1 has 7 apples. Row 2 has 7 cookies. Vertical dotted lines divide the cookies into 7 columns so there are 7 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5dede9bd017270ba0451eaeb2fcb5d494990de17)

Each apple has a pair, so there are an even number of apples.

In this image, there are $\blueE{18}$ apples.

![3 rows of apples. Each row has 6 apples. Vertical dotted lines divide the apples into 3 columns and horizontal dotted lines divide the apples into 3 rows. There are 9 pairs of apples.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9f7cf3d61992c348e4849d9245e3aa4b88c73b52)

Each apple has a pair, so there are an even number of apples.

In this image, there are $\maroonD{11}$ apples.

![2 columns of apples. Column 1 has 6 apples. Column 2 has 5 apples. Horizontal dotted lines divide the apples into 6 rows so there are 5 pairs of apples with 1 extra apple.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/442eb82a9ae37bd1dd66aed8986c3767762c5da0)

Each apple does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of apples.

This image shows an odd number of apples:

![2 columns of apples. Column 1 has 6 apples. Column 2 has 5 apples. ](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/42983aa23e9288ca21d6cdeb380f4b18dab5d8d6)

question.content:
**Which image shows an odd number of apples?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![2 rows of apples. Each row has 7 apples.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/62d8a3f9d928ac340efe5912d505401437c3052e)
![2 columns of apples. Column 1 has 6 apples. Column 2 has 5 apples. ](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/42983aa23e9288ca21d6cdeb380f4b18dab5d8d6)
![3 rows of apples. Each row has 6 apples. ](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/96f5eccedfea9170161ef41470fc06d7ee8173c5)
